I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility (PPIAF) was established in July 1999 
at the initiative of the governments of Japan and the United Kingdom, working closely with the 
World Bank. This multidonor technical assistance (TA) facility was set up to assist developing 
countries to improve the quality of their infrastructure through private sector involvement. PPIAF 
assistance helps  to  facilitate  private  sector  involvement  in  financing,  ownership,  operation, 
rehabilitation,  maintenance  or  management  of  infrastructure  services.  Eligible  infrastructure 
services  assisted  by  PPIAF  are  roads,  ports,  airports,  railways,  electricity  supply, 
telecommunications,  solid  waste,  water  supply  and  sewerage,  and  gas  transmission  and 
distribution. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) joined PPIAF in 2001 by contributing an initial 
$250,000 to the trust fund to cover the 12 months from 1 January 2001.1 Thereafter, ADB 
renewed its funding support for 5 years to the end of 2006.2 The present TA for $500,000 
represents a fourth cash contribution to the PPIAF trust fund, covering membership for 2 years 
from 1 January 2007 to 31 December 2008. As a partner in the facility, ADB strengthens its role 
in mobilizing private resources for infrastructure development in the Asia and Pacific region.3 
The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Mission and Organization. PPIAF’s mission is to help to eliminate poverty and achieve 
sustainable development in developing countries by facilitating private sector involvement in 
infrastructure. PPIAF pursues its mission through two mechanisms: (i) technical assistance to 
governments in developing countries on strategies and measures to tap the full potential of 
private involvement in infrastructure, and (ii) identification, dissemination and promotion of good 
practices on matters related to private involvement in infrastructure in developing countries. 
 
4.  As a member, ADB is represented on the PPIAF Program Council (PC), which includes 
representatives of all contributing donor agencies. As of June 2006, there were 15 members 
including ADB. The Program Management Unit (PMU) manages the day-to-day operations of 
PPIAF in accordance with a general strategy and annual work programs approved by the PC. 
The  PC  meets  once  a  year  to  review  the  strategic  direction  of  the  PPIAF  program, 
achievements  and  financing  requirements.  The  World  Bank  acts  as  the  PPIAF  trust  fund 
administrator. PPIAF has established four field-based regional coordination offices to assist in 
executing the PPIAF work program in Nairobi, Kenya; Dakar, Senegal; Manila, Philippines; and 
New Delhi, India. An independent Technical Advisory Panel, comprising leading international 
experts in different aspects of private provision of infrastructure, supports the PC. 
 
5.  Resources and Projects Approved. As of 30 June 2006, donors have contributed a 
total of $122 million to PPIAF, including more than $2.1 million of net investment income. 
Information on donor contributions in core funds and noncore funds is in Table 1.  The noncore 
funds focus on the donors’ agenda in either a particular country or a particular activity. The core 
funds can be used for general PPIAF activities. The World Bank and the governments of Japan 
and the United Kingdom have accounted for the bulk of resources to support PPIAF programs.

6.  From its inception to 30 June 2006, PPIAF approved 505 grants amounting to more than 
$111 million. As of 30 June 2006, the PPIAF portfolio included activities in 108 countries as well 
as 90 regional activities. In addition, PPIAF mobilized additional cofinancing of $8.4 million from 
other donors and through contributions from governments. A review of PPIAF-funded activities 
at the end of 20064 showed the following outcomes: (i) 83 infrastructure investment transactions 
were facilitated; (ii) 43 public-private partnership (PPP) laws and regulations were drafted, of 
which 29 were enacted; (iii) 40 regulatory institutions were established or strengthened; (iv) 
implementation  of  sector  reform  programs  was  supported;  and  (v)  best  practices  were 
disseminated to more than 15,000 people through attendance at international and regional 
conferences and workshops. 
 
7.  PPIAF’s FY2006 Program. Fiscal 2006 saw continued demand for PPIAF assistance as 
the experience with private participation reinforced the critical importance of sector reform, 
enabling environments and government capacity to ensure effective results from PPPs. In 
response, PPIAF approved funding for 93 activities for a total of $17.4 million in TA grants, 
maintaining its performance levels from the previous fiscal year. Significant elements of the 
work  program  reflected  three  major  trends,  as  follows:  (i)  PPP  arrangements  reflect  great 
diversity  ranging  from  concessions  to  nonequity  models  such  as  leases  and  management 
contracts, (ii) reform efforts are increasingly taking into account the need for building consensus 
and recognizing transition costs, and (iii) reinforcement of the basics of sector reform and 
project preparation is critical in realizing the full benefits of PPPs.

8.  Emerging  Best  Practice.  The  objective  of  disseminating  knowledge  and  the  main 
lessons emerging in the private infrastructure market in recent years drives PPIAF’s knowledge 
management portfolio. Resources are directed to (i) providing ongoing support to activities 
aimed  at  improving  regulatory  systems  for  infrastructure  provision,  and  (ii)  analyzing  the 
increased activity by “nontypical” private investors and operators, to highlight the wider array of 
investment  options  made  apparent  by  this  emerging  trend.  To  strengthen  outreach  and 
dissemination, PPIAF launched Gridlines in 2006, a series of four-page notes that provide 
examples of best practice on emerging and important themes in the environment for PPPs.  
 
9.  Rationale for Continued ADB Membership in PPIAF. The infrastructure demands of 
the Asia-Pacific region are immense and the public sector alone cannot bridge the financing and 
efficiency gaps. Development of private sector involvement in infrastructure is crucial to the 
sustained economic growth of the region. Continued membership of PPIAF allows ADB to 
access an existing partnership of all major donors that will enhance the knowledge content of 
ongoing and proposed private sector participation (PSP) projects. An active partnership with 
PPIAF provides a significant opportunity to keep abreast of major initiatives in the private 
infrastructure sector. 
 
10.  There is strong demand for PSP support among ADB’s developing member countries 
(DMCs). Demand is indicated by PPIAF’s 160 TA projects valued at $37.2 million,5 which 
represent about 34% of all PPIAF activities. PPIAF’s activities play an important role in assisting 
DMCs to meet their needs. Through continued membership, ADB can further enhance its role in 
promoting private sector development of infrastructure in the region, allowing it to leverage its 
resources to carry out critical studies on private sector and infrastructure development, and to 
provide staff with continued access to valuable global knowledge. ADB acts as a donor to 
PPIAF and also as an important user of the facility’s resources. Since it joined PPIAF, ADB has 
made use of $2.2 million of PPIAF funding support for 10 TA projects to promote private 
infrastructure. (The ratio between ADB’s contribution and PPIAF funding is about 2:1.)  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  In pursuit of ADB’s overarching objective to reduce poverty in DMCs through sustainable 
economic  development,  the  TA  aims  to  support  PPIAF  in  facilitating  greater  PSP  in 
infrastructure in accordance with ADB’s private sector development strategy and the broad 
directions under ADB’s Medium-Term Strategy II. The TA will allow ADB to continue to be an 
active member of PPIAF, to build on its partnership with other major donors in this area, and to 
assist DMCs in resource mobilization. It will also help ADB achieve knowledge sharing through 
access to studies on PSP in infrastructure projects conducted under PPIAF. As an active 
member of the PC, ADB also reviews all private infrastructure TA projects funded through 
PPIAF (which are largely from the World Bank), provides comments, and prevents duplication 
by other donors. (The TA framework is in Appendix 1.)

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  Funding support from this TA will enable ADB to continue its important partnership with 
PPIAF. ADB’s continued membership will provide additional benefits to ADB’s DMCs as well as 
additional resources for focusing on promoting private infrastructure sector development in 
DMCs.  Overall,  the  TA  supports  a  range  of  advisory  and  related  activities,  including  the 
following. 
 
(i)  Framing  infrastructure  development  strategies  to  take  full  advantage  of  the 
potential for private involvement. 
 
(ii)  Building consensus on appropriate policy, regulatory and institutional reforms. 
 
(iii)  Designing and implementing specific policy, regulatory and institutional reforms. 
 
(iv)  Supporting  the  design  and  implementation  of  pioneering  projects  and 
transactions. 
 
(v)  Building  government  capacity  to  design  and  execute  private  infrastructure 
arrangements and regulate private service providers. 
 
13.  The TA will provide membership contribution to PPIAF’s core funds. It will thus help 
meet the cost of consulting services recruited by ADB as well as other eligible expenses for 
undertaking ADB-initiated PPIAF projects designed to encourage PSP in infrastructure and 
create an enabling environment for PPPs. Through its membership in the PC, ADB will also play 
an important role in selecting PPIAF project activities. In most cases, these projects will further 
the poverty reduction objectives of ADB and generally complement the studies proposed by 
ADB in its private sector development strategy. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  ADB will contribute $500,000 to PPIAF, which will be used to finance consulting services 
and other costs.6 The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. 
Disbursements  against  the  trust  fund  account  will  have  the  prior  approval  of  the  ADB-
designated task manager. The TA will be implemented from 1 January 2007 to 31 October 2009, 
the latest agreed utilization closing date. ADB’s contribution will be provided after the successful 
discussion and signing of the letter of agreement between the trust fund administrator (the 
World Bank) and ADB for the period covered. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The implementation arrangements for ADB’s involvement in PPIAF are set forth in and 
governed by the PPIAF trust fund agreement and the guidelines signed by PPIAF and ADB on 
29 June 2005, as amended by the amendment letter signed on 5 October 2006 (see Appendix 
2). Under the amended agreement, overall project management of ADB-initiated PPIAF projects 
is delegated to ADB. As such, procurement of goods and services will follow ADB’s Guidelines

16.  ADB will administer the TA. Administration of the TA is expected to be coordinated with 
the Energy, Transport and Water Division (RSID) of the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department,  which  will  assist  the  regional  departments  and  facilitate  the  preparation  of 
applications  for  PPIAF  grants  that  support  promotion  of  private  sector  investment  in 
infrastructure. RSID will coordinate ADB-initiated PPIAF projects, act as an intermediary with 
PMU, and also work with PMU to monitor closely all ongoing ADB-initiated PPIAF projects. 
Once individual projects are approved, responsibility for implementation will lie with the division 
that initiates the PPIAF proposal. 
 
17.  Governance and Organization Structure. PPIAF is governed by the PC, consisting of 
representatives from contributing donors. The PC is responsible for defining PPIAF policies and 
strategies, approving the indicative annual work program and financial plan, and reviewing PPIA 
performance. The PC also is responsible for approving individual project submissions. The PC 
meets once a year to review the strategic direction of the PPIAF program. The Technical 
Advisory  Panel,  composed  of  up  to  six  independent  experts  in  matters  related  to  private 
involvement in infrastructure in developing countries, ensures the quality and relevance of 
PPIAF-financed activities. PMU is responsible for the day-to-day management of PPIAF in 
pursuit of its mandate. PMU reports to the PC at least quarterly through the PC chair. The World 
Bank’s Vice-President for Sustainable Development chairs the PC. The details are in Appendix 
2. 
 
18.  Financial Arrangements. PPIAF has a two-tier financial structure comprising a core 
fund and noncore funds. The core fund contains a pool of resources that can be used for any 
activity falling within the work program approved by the PC. The funds may be applied to 
governance costs, country-specific activities and activities across several countries. Noncore 
funds include donor agency restrictions relating to specific themes or activities. ADB will enter 
into an agreement for its contributions to PPIAF with the World Bank. 
 
19.  Past Performance. Since its membership in PPIAF, ADB has made a total contribution 
of $1.25 million and was granted a total of $2.2 million for 10 ADB-initiated PPIAF projects. 
ADB-initiated PPIAF projects are listed in Appendix 3. ADB has not only participated in an 
important  global  initiative  supporting  infrastructure  development,  but  it  also  has  leveraged 
resources to support its program in this area. 
 
20.  Results from the independent strategic review of PPIAF operations in the past 5 years 
(1999–2004) validated the relevance of the facility’s core mandate of supporting infrastructure 
services  through  PPPs.  With  strong  donor  support,  PPIAF  is  a  good  example  of  global 
partnership working to catalyze private sector investments in infrastructure. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

GOVERNANCE AND ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE OF THE PUBLIC-PRIVATE 
INFRASTRUCTURE ADVISORY FACILITY 
 
A.  Program Council 
 
1.  The Program Council (PC) includes all agencies contributing to PPIAF. It is responsible 
for (i) defining the policies and strategies of the Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility 
(PPIAF), (ii) approving the indicative annual work program and financial plan, and (iii) reviewing 
PPIAF performance. The PC generally meets once a year, but it approves PPIAF proposals 
throughout the year on a “no-objection” basis. As a member of the PC, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) has authority to approve or object to each PPIAF proposal. PPIAF has established 
four  field-based  regional  coordination  offices  in  New  Delhi,  India;  Nairobi,  Kenya;  Manila, 
Philippines; and Dakar, Senegal.  
 
B.  Program Management Unit  
 
2.  The Program Management Unit (PMU) is responsible for PPIAF’s day-to-day operations. 
PMU reports to the PC at least quarterly through the PC chair. PMU’s staff members are 
recruited internationally for their relevant expertise. The unit’s main responsibilities include (i) 
reviewing  proposals  for  PPIAF  assistance;  (ii)  recommending  approval  to  the  PC;  (iii) 
maintaining effective relationships with contributors, recipient governments, the private sector 
and  stakeholders;  (iv)  proposing  and  administering  the  PPIAF  work  plan  and  budget;  (v) 
managing the disbursement of funds; and (vi) overseeing the operations of regional coordination 
offices. The regional coordination offices assist PMU to execute the PPIAF work program in 
their respective jurisdictions. 
 
C.  Technical Advisory Panel  
 
3.  The Technical Advisory Panel comprises up to six independent specialists with expertise 
in matters related to private involvement in infrastructure in developing countries, and ensures 
the quality and relevance of PPIAF-funded activities.  
 
D.  PPIAF Governing Structure 
 
4.  PPIAF is a partnership technical assistance facility that is governed by the PC. Each 
agency contributing to PPIAF has an equal seat on the PC, regardless of that agency’s level of 
contribution. This means all contributors receive the same information about PPIAF activities, 
funds management and impacts. All contributors on the PC receive every application valued at 
more than $75,000, along with a summary describing the proposed activity, and may approve or 
reject the project. All applications below $75,000 go to PMU for approval. An application is 
rejected if any one contributor rejects it. These rights and responsibilities are set out in PPIAF’s 
Charter (see http://www.ppiaf.org). 
 
5.  PMU is tasked with day-to-day management of PPIAF, monitoring funds and activities, 
coordinating  the  PC  and  the  Technical  Advisory  Panel,  and  preparing  the  summary  and 
presentation of applications for approval. A program manager was hired by the PC, which 
conducted interviews and ranked candidates in joint session.

E.  Eligibility for PPIAF Products 
 
6.  Countries eligible to receive PPIAF assistance are those in the list of aid recipients of the 
Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) Development Assistance 
Committee. However, as required by PPIAF trust fund documents, only member countries of 
ADB  in  the  Asia-Pacific  region  are  eligible  to  receive  assistance  from  the  ADB  technical 
assistance (TA) grant. Project activities submitted for approval must (i) be consistent with the 
PPIAF mission; (ii) have government commitment; (iii) provide an additional flow of resources; 
(iv)  have  quality  assurances;  and  (v)  meet  regional,  sectoral,  environmental  and  social 
responsibilities. 
 
F.   Criteria for Approval of Activities 
 
7.  As stated in PPIAF’s Charter (Article 17), activities must meet strict criteria before they 
can  be  approved.  The  criteria  include  demonstrated  commitment  from  the  beneficiary 
government in the case of country-specific activities, and proof of aid coordination. Specifically, 
the activity must “not conflict with programs of activities being undertaken” by any of PPIAF’s 
contributors.  Article  17  also  restricts  PPIAF  funding  to  those  activities  that  require  a  “net 
additional flow of resources,” meaning that PPIAF does not fund projects that could receive 
funding from another source. For example, if an application involves the preparation of a project 
that will eventually be funded from loans from the World Bank or ADB, PPIAF will not accept the 
application. It would be assumed that the project preparation budget should be available from 
the lending institution. To be clear, this means PPIAF does not contribute grant funds to World 
Bank projects, and would not do so for any other aid agency. A main reason for PMU rejection 
of an application is due diligence showing the availability of other more suitable sources of 
funding, including credit lines from aid agencies.  
 
8.  Proposals for PPIAF assistance that meet the threshold eligibility requirements of the 
Technical Advisory Panel shall be assessed against the following criteria. 
 
(i)  Consistency  with  PPIAF  mission.  All  activities  must  be  consistent  with 
PPIAF’s  overarching  objective  of  helping  to  eliminate  poverty  and  achieve 
sustainable development. 
 
(ii)  Government  commitment. Country-specific activities may be undertaken 
only where there is clear evidence of government commitment to the activity. 
The government in question must approve of the proposed activity in writing.1 
 
(iii)  Donor  coordination.  PPIAF  activities  will  be  undertaken  in  a  way  that 
promotes effective coordination with the activities of official donors. In particular, 
country-specific activities may be undertaken only if PMU is satisfied that the 
proposed activity does not conflict with programs or activities being undertaken 
by the World Bank Group, other PPIAF contributors or, to the extent this is easily 
verifiable, by other donors. 
 
(iv)  Additional resources. PPIAF is intended to result in a net additional flow of 
resources to relevant activities. Accordingly, funding for a proposed activity

should not be available more conveniently from other sources, including loans 
from  international  financial  institutions,  grants  from  other  programs  or  a

(v)  Cofinancing.  PPIAF is able to pay up to 100% of the costs of an activity. 
However,  cofinancing  from  a  recipient  government  and  other  sources  is 
encouraged. 
 
(vi)  Value  for  money.  PPIAF  activities  should aim  to  ensure  value  for  money, 
including  adopting  the  lowest  cost  strategies  consistent  with  appropriate 
standards of quality. 
 
(vii)  Quality  assurance. Applications for PPIAF funding should contain indicators 
against which activity quality can be assessed. Larger activities should usually 
include appropriate consultative and quality review mechanisms. 
 
(viii)  Regional and sectoral balance. Subject to the work program approved by the 
PC, activities financed from the core fund should aim to maintain a reasonable 
balance across developing regions and across eligible infrastructure sectors. 
 
(ix)  Environmental and social responsibility. Where a project to be supported by 
PPIAF is anticipated to have significant potential adverse environmental or social 
consequences, appropriate measures must be adopted to ensure an objective 
and  transparent  assessment.  When  required,  PPIAF  can  finance  such 
assessments. 
 
(x)  Expenditures.  Eligible  expenditures  for  PPIAF  activities  may  include  the 
following. 
 
(a)  Costs associated with identifying, supervising and delivering the activity. 
(b)  Costs associated with preparing and disseminating information produced 
by PPIAF. 
(c)  Costs associated with organizing workshops, seminars or conferences, 
including costs related to participation by relevant international experts 
and, in appropriate cases, representatives of recipient governments. 
(d)  Costs of visit programs for appropriate developing country personnel. 
(e)  Other expenditures related directly to the fulfillment of PPIAF’s mandate. 
 
G.  Administrative and Procurement Procedures for ADB-Initiated PPIAF TA Projects 
 
9.  All members of PPIAF sign a trust agreement with the World Bank, the depository of all 
PPIAF funds. Trust fund agreements for the first three ADB contributions were completed in 
2001, 2003 and 2005. On 12 March 2003, ADB and the World Bank signed the “Notes on 
administrative and procurement procedures for PPIAF-approved activities co-tasked managed 
by the ADB and the World Bank.” This document provided guidelines for implementing ADB-
initiated PPIAF projects. However, the implementation procedures proved to be complicated 
and  inefficient  due  to  differing  processes,  causing  delays  in  project  implementation.  To 
streamline procedures, an amendment to the trust fund agreement for the third ADB contribution 
was signed by ADB and the World Bank on 5 October 2006. Under the amended agreement, 
project management of ADB-initiated PPIAF projects will be delegated to ADB and procurement

amended from time to time) and Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
H.  Reporting and Audit Requirements 
 
10.  PC  members  receive  a  quarterly  financial  statement  (unaudited)  and  a  quarterly 
progress report on the status of approved activities. They also receive an annual report on all 
PPIAF activities and summary financial statements, no later than 6 months after the end of 
PPIAF’s fiscal year. The World Bank, as trust fund administrator, will provide members an 
annual  management  statement,  together  with  attestation  from  the  external  auditor  of  the 
satisfactory performance of the procedures and controls used in administering PPIAF funds. 
External reviews and financial audits of PPIAF activities may be performed at the request of the 
PC and contributors with respect to their contributions. ADB will request an annual review and 
financial audit of its contributions, and expenditures incurred.
